title: Great screenplay with two great performing artists
content: This movie told a story when America and the American whites were so deeply biased to the black Americans. With this movie, some deep wounds would have been healed, some injustice when treating we human beings would be justified. It also showed how two extremely different kinds of people, with different growing up backgrounds, well educated or not, through a long journey, both gradually open up and tried to accommodate each other and finally completely merged as a one great American that should be, although came a bit late.This movie also felt like an educational road trip, both characters were at first so stereotyped biased by their own cultural and ethnic backgrounds, the ways how they each grew up, a complete different kind of day-and-night races, but through endeavor from each side, they have both transformed into a better person, not just relying on each other, but also educated each other, and proved that racial differences was the least thing to be bothered. Loyalty and friendship through the long road trip gradually grew organically.The guy who threw two water glasses just used by two black plumbers in the very beginning, then transformed into a person who'd sacrifice anything to protect the person whose race he used to dislike even hated so much, it was told by the storyline so naturally and subtly, simply allowing us, the viewers, to understand our own morality and emotions with deeper insight, a soul search and recognition to we human beings, and completely change us like those two characters in the movie; more open-minded with a well balanced conservatism and liberalism.A great road trip story was told here.

title: Nice, Nice, & More Nice
content: The Green Book I guess you could say had good intentions but unfortunately it handles the subject and story with kids gloves. It's as though the whole film is told through rose colored glasses and that leaves the viewer with nothing to really sink out teeths into. It looks good and the performances and costumes are all well done. I wanted to like Green Book more but I found it just a little too predictable. I can see there are quite a few folks who seem to really enjoy this film and I'm not advising against seeing it, if you're genuinely curious give it a viewing and see what you think, it just left me wanting for more though.

title: Great acting, heartwarming story.
content: As far as on the road, buddy movies go, I'd say Green Book is my new favourite. This was marvellously directed by Peter Farrelly in his first solo venture, apart from his brother Bobby. The movie, though it has some good laughs in it, is clearly more of a dramatic movie and Peter Farelly's first one in his career. I guess he knows how to do great drama too! The performances were stellar. Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali are terrific together and have a great chemistry in this. The musical scenes were tremendously performed by Mahershala Ali and on top of that the score was great too. For a movie about race and prejudice in the early 60's south it will undoubtedly win you over with its heartwarming touch. Funny and dramatic. This is a great holiday movie. 9/10

title: A feel-good film.
content: Green Book tells the true story of Tony Lip(Viggo Mortensen) an Italian-American bouncer/chauffeur, who Dr. Don Shirley(Mahershala Ali) an African-American pianist hires, when he tours several venues in the deep south of America, during the 1960s.Green Book is a brilliant movie. Director Peter Farrelly has given us a film, that effortlessly blends both comedic & dramatic elements. There are scenes where you will be guffawing & there are also scenes that are emotional & leave you teary-eyed. The gorgeous locales have been captured beautifully by cinematographer, Sean Porter. The performances are the highlight of the movie. Viggo Mortensen is outstanding as Tony Lip. The physical transformation that Mortensen went through to embody his character, is commendable. Mahershala Ali is spectacular as Dr. Don Shirley. Ali's nuanced yet powerful performance, deserves all the awards coming his way. The effortless chemistry between Viggo Mortensen & Mahershala Ali, is what makes this film flawless. Linda Cardellini is fantastic as Dolores. The supporting cast is superb. Green Book is a must watch. Go, be entertained & moved.

title: "Funny, beautiful and loving portrait of friendship."
content:
GREEN BOOK follows a Viggo Mortenson a man who has a simple life and a loving wife.
One day, he gets a job to drive a pianoist, Dr. Shirley (Mahershala Ali) (Moonlight, True Detective)
They both form a special bond and deeply connect, even though they at times fight with each other.
The movie deals with racism in the south in a very interesting way.
Dr. Shirley is racially profiled and treated harshly by others, due to the color of his skin, what is beautiful is that Viggo accepts him for who he is, and does not judge him.
The movie isn't sad, heartbreaking, it's beautiful, most movies about subject matters such as racism tend to be sad and hard to watch, however, Green Book avoids that.
It's an easy to watch movie that deals with racism, and it's not sad!

title: Excellent screen-writing makes a politically correct buddy film
content: This film revolves around the social hierarchy of the 1960s, where we follow protagonist Dr. Shirley played by Mahershala Ali. Viggo Mortensen is his personal driver for his piano tour down south.There is a very well-made screenplay, complemented brilliantly by the excellent performances by Ali and Mortensen. I believe that Mortensen nailed it particularly as the bouncer type, and I would have loved to see him win the academy award for best actor in a leading role rather than seeing Ali win again for supporting.I must say that the script is very PC but it is still a great buddy film that I can highly recommended - a life-affirming film with a great message.

title: Crowd pleasing thanks to its humor and performances, but ultimately overly predictable, bland, and forgettable
content: I have few big complaints about Green Book, but just an hour after watching it little of it stayed in my mind. It's a dramedy focused on the relationship between a working class white guy and a black pianist in the 1960s. Mortensen and Ali are both excellent in their roles, with Mortensen bringing some depth to an exaggeratedly written character and Ali bringing a balance of professionalism and emotion. Their relationship certainly has its share of humor, and it is fun to be along for the ride as they banter. I didn't think the racial elements of their relationships and identities were well explored, with the exception of Ali's monologue about how he doesn't fit in with any community. Mortensen was overtly racist early on, and there's no real explanation for why he's quickly so willing to work for a black high class man and put those prejudices aside. The differences in viewpoints and nuance were largely brushed aside in favor of a broader, optimistic arc where both of them are just good friends who save the other from racial/class problems when they need it. The ending does a good job of bringing full circle the themes of courage and integrity, but they still feel quite surface level and manufactured for easy, light satisfaction. The humor is fine and adds to the movie but isn't essential to it. It's a movie that's easy to sit back and go along with, but a hard one to think deeply about and come away with new elements to ponder. It's a crowd pleaser, but felt all to predictable and pandery to be memorable.

title: Most Likely Oscar 2019 Best Picture Winner
content:
Green Book Review:Green Book is inspired by the true friendship of Tony Lip (Viggo Mortensen), a working class Italian-American bouncer and Dr. Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali), an African-American pianist, as Tony Lip drives Dr. Shirley on his venue tour in the 1960s in the southern states. This is the movie, other than A Star is Born, that has been getting the biggest Oscar buzz this season. It seemed like an interesting plot and looked really good. I've given out 4 A+ scores this year, one being for the miniseries Sharp Objects, and I'm happy to say Green Book joins that group. I loved every minute of this movie! The story by Peter Farrelly was so good. Definitely will get a nomination for Best Original Screenplay, though I do think Roma will end up winning it. The dialogue worked. The pacing was good. There was just so much emotion put into this. As the tour gets deeper into the South, Dr. Shirley experiences more racism and you just had no words to describe all of the emotion and feelings put into those scenes. The performances by the two actors are the best of all year. Viggo Mortensen will win Best Actor. His portrayal of Tony Lip was amazing. His best performance yet. He was a lovable character. And it's a character that has flaws and it's acknowledged throughout and Viggo knew how to do that. Mahershala Ali will for sure win his second Oscar, first for playing Juan in Moonlight, playing Dr. Shirley. This is his best role to date. There were scenes that made me laugh and some bringing tears. This is a lock for Best Supporting Actor. I loved Linda Cardellini as Delores but I don't think she'll be recognized for her role. Peter Farrelly's direction was great. He has made some horrendous films in the past, one being Movie 43, but he did very well and could get a nomination for Best Director, probably won't win however. The score by Kris Bowers was very good. It was a mix of classical music that Dr. Shirley played and 60s jazz. I think he'll get a nomination for Best Original Score. Not too many scores have been released for upcoming films so it's hard to tell what he's up against though there are a few from earlier this year that could get nominated. The cinematography was good but not good enough for the nomination. In all honesty, so far this is the film that I think will win Best Picture at the Oscars 2019 (I will put my top 10 Best Picture Predictions below). It had so much to say and I think it's a film everyone should see. It's relevant and I will say my favorite Christmas movie to date. I was disappointed to see that it didn't make too much at the box office yet, only making 14.0 million and only #10 at the the top box office for its second week into its release. It was promoted at theaters but not many theaters got it. I had to go all the way to Appleton to see it and it was in a small theater that was packed. I was happy to see how many people went to see it. Overall you should see the movie when you get the chance. I don't think you could hate it.My Grade: A+My Oscar 2019 Best Picture Predictions so far (they're pretty close to the Gold Derby Predictions):1. Green Book
2. Roma
3. A Star is Born
4. If Beale Street Could Talk
5. The Favourite
6. Vice
7. BlacKkKlansman
8. First Man
9. Black Panther (it's really getting a lot of buzz)
10. Can You Ever Forgive Me?

title: Funny fluffy comedy about a oppressive time in American history.
content: Green Book certainly stirred up controversy when it unexpectedly won Best Picture at the 2019 Academy Awards. I personally didn't care as I lost interest in the Oscars completely (these are the people that nominated Black Panther for Best Picture). Certainly is the film in my Top 5 favorites of 2018, not really. That doesn't mean however that Green Book isn't an endearing, enjoyable and above all funny film about friendship and acceptance. The themes of this film have been highlighted around a zillion times in other films such as The Help. However that doesn't mean that the formula is broken. I for one appreciated this films humor, performances and story. A tough Italian brute (Viggo Mortensen) is looking for a new job. He is hired by an African American musician (Mahershala Ali) to drive him through the Southern States in the early 1960s for a tour. The film wisely goes for humor over melodrama which is what sets it apart from all the other films about this topic. Not that the film doesn't have dramatic moments, in fact these are all the more effective because the two main characters were so likeable and funny. Mortensen gave such a heartwarming performance. His character is a brute, he doesn't mind getting physical when someone pisses him off. But his character also expressed such an aura of warmth were the audience simply gravitated towards him. He doesn't understand the racism, he doesn't get the absolute treacherous and human rights violating laws of Jim Crow under which African Americans suffered. However the film wisely never preaches about the privileged white man not knowing the truth, it just shows it, plain and simple. Ali too gave a terrific performance, his character had a sense of sophistication and coolness even in intense situations. It is incredibly heart wrenching to see such a professional guy who lives his passion pushed to his breaking point by his societies' racist rules. Overall there is not much else to say about Green Book. The themes are obvious and the film doesn't attempt to hide it. Mortensen and Ali are terrific and share great chemistry. A heartwarming family film that allows children to have a more sanitized look into America's darkest points of history. No 12 Years A Slave but still a good time.

title: Heartbreaking and heartwarming

I mean, the word "racism" itself probably didn't even exist at the time. But the story of Tony Lip and Don Shirley's growing friendship brought me great comfort and I'm really grateful there were such good people, however few, among all the herds of bigots.

title: Decent, enjoyable but standard prestige film based on a true story
content: Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali give stellar performances in this true story about a NYC club employee and bodyguard who is hired by a classical pianist from Carnegie Hall to drive him through his performance tour across the South in the early 1960s, during which they develop a solid bond, despite their considerable educational and socioeconomic differences.I would call this film decent, light entertainment. It definitely offers a glimpse into how impressive Mortensen's range is an actor. The same actor who gave compelling performances in films like "A Dangerous Method" and "Captain Fantastic" is thoroughly riveting to watch here as he disappears into the role of "Tony Lip" Vallelonga and Ali is impressive as Don Shirley, a Jamaican-American musician who became well-known in his era.This film doesn't break too much ground, in all honesty. It's good diverting cinema but as a film released during Oscar season, it's fairly run-of-the-mill with no real surprises. But I do give Peter Farrelly a lot of credit for stepping out of his usual repertoire and giving us a different genre to look at within his filmography. Recommended.

title: A white streetwise bouncer and an articulate black pianist tour the Deep South in 1962
content: A tough, working class Italian New Yawker (Viggo Mortensen) is forced to take a gig driving a refined African-American concert pianist (Mahershala Ali) through the Midwest and Deep South in 1962. Linda Cardellini plays the wife of the Italian."Green Book" (2018) was inspired by the real-life story and written by the son of Tony Lip (Mortensen). Like all great dramas, it's compelling from the get-go and the road movie approach provides an entertaining and revelatory string of episodes, not to mention occasionally amusing. While the movie's been accused of reverse racism, it's actually balanced, showing plenty of poor, inarticulate blacks and vice versa. The message is to base your perceptions on the individual rather than ignorant generalizations.The film runs 2 hours, 10 minutes, and was shot in New York City and Louisiana.GRADE: A

Through great acting both main characters are brought to life as real life sympatic persons. The story (kind of road movie) is depicted from an actual begin '60 experience. It's about a friendship built against the background of segregated US. Both the (mild) portayal of US segregation and how the respect and friendship evolve makes 'the green book' a strong advocate for respect. Go see and enjoy!

title: This is one of those films you never want to end
content: Green Book (2018) is a movie my wife and I watched on Prime shortly after it was released to that streaming service. The storyline follows a New York City Italian that is rough around the edges that has been hired to drive a black pianist as he tours the south in the 1960s. Their very different demeanors, lifestyles and skill sets are a shock to each other but they do their best to learn from each other and meet in the middle so they can both be successful with their responsibilities. This movie is directed by Peter Farrelly (Dumb and Dumber and Kingpin) and stars Viggo Mortensen (Lord of the Rings), Mahershala Ali (Luke Cage) and Linda Cardellini (Brokeback Mountain). The storyline for this is very intricate and brilliantly written. The subplots on the Italian, the world renowned pianist and how those individuals were perceived through various interactions in the south were fascinating and well presented. The dialogue was well written and the cast delivers fantastic performances. The end is rewarding and this is one of those films you never want to end. I would score this an easy 10/10 and strongly recommend it.

title: Great Movie
content: This movie details the relationship between pianist Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali) and a bouncer named Tony (Viggo Mortensen) who is hired to drive him through the Deep South in 1962 for a two month concert tour. He is to make sure he reaches all the concert destinations and to keep him safe if any trouble should arise, and plenty does. The acting is wonderful, especially by Viggo Mortensen, who portrays an Italian from New York who is a bit rough around the edges compared to the dignified Shirley. Plenty of humor is interspersed within the poignant relationship that develops between the two men. This movie is based on a true story when segregation was the "norm", and the Green Book was a travel guide for African Americans that listed hotels that were available for them to stay in, which were often subpar if best. If you are looking for a fast paced thriller, this movie might not be for you, but if you like movies that show a piece of history and true to life heart-warming stories, then this one is for you!

title: Enjoyable movie in spite of its flaws
content: Green Book tells the presumably true story of white racist guy hired as the chauffeur for a black musician doing a tour of the deep south. It's predictable, following the well-worn path to racial understanding of similar films, but it's got solid performances and is engaging throughout.There have been various criticisms of this movie. Don Shirley's family says its ridiculous to claim he'd never eaten fried chicken before having it forced on him by a white guy, and that's probably true. But it works as a way to contrast the plebeian white guy with the sophisticated black man, and it's silly to expect any Hollywood movie to not be at least half fiction.(It's hard to know who's telling the truth. Shirley's family has complained a lot, but from what I've read they don't seem to have been that close to him. The movie was written by the chauffeur's son, who says Don Shirley himself approved it, but the guy also echoed Donald Trump's lie that thousands of American Muslims cheered during 9/11, which makes me consider him inherently untrustworthy.)The movie has also been criticized as yet another movie funneling racism through a white lens; this is the chauffeur's story, not Shirley's. But because a movie is part of an unfortunate trend doesn't mean that individual movie isn't good, it just means Hollywood has trouble breaking out of its boxes.The title does, however, bug me. The Green Book was a guide on where to find hotels where black people could stay at a time when many hotels were whites only. It's a good example of what black people had to deal with, it was written for black people by black people, the existence of the book is a condemnation of the white culture that made it necessary, and even though it's a fairly insignificant plot point this is the title they chose. This is a movie about a white guy learning about racism; why make the title something so much a part of a particular black experience? It feels a little like theft.Still, I really enjoyed it. I wouldn't say it was super memorable, and it seems like a movie I'll have pretty much forgotten in a year (so maybe I should give it a 7?) yet it's mix of humor and pathos make it a very enjoyable experience.

title: Nitpicking from an italian over a good movie
content:
I'm an italian girl from northeast italy, so not part of most of the origins of italoamericans (mostly from south italy, we migrated in the US but more elsewhere) nor black, nor american, so my take has this POV precisely. To me a film is good when it entertains me (and i studied cinema at uni) and this movie does its job in that. It also has beautiful photography, nice dialogues, nice comic parts, nice drama still remaining realistic. So I'll pass all the good things and i'll nitpick extensively the few ones i didn't like. In casual order:
1) viggo mortesen can pass as an italian as i could pass for a chinese. He's clearly scandinavian and a hair painture can't change that. title: Enjoyable story of an unlikely friendship
content: Based on a true story in the US deep south during the 60s, 'Green Book' is an enjoyable and moving film about an unlikely friendship between a black jazz musician and his white bodyguard and driver. It's a nice story and the film does a good job at balancing the humour and drama so that it feels neither too light or heavy.'Green Book' is well-written and looks great. The two main characters, Tony and Don, are brilliantly played by Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali respectively. They work well together and share great chemistry, with some very funny moments and individual scenes.If I had one criticism, 'Green Book' does feel quite cliché and somewhat forced in getting its message across. Of course, race relations were always going to be a big part of this film as it is set in a time in American history when racism was rife, but I do often feel films like this try too hard to make a statement rather than simply tell the story.

title: Let's you chuckle about a rough subject and time
content: I went to the theater thinking this was fiction. Wrong. It's a darn good film with superb acting by Viggo Mortenson (Tony Lip) and Mahershala Ali (Dr. Don Shirley). The interplay between the obnxious Italian bouncer (Tony Lip) and the stuffy black vitruoso brought chuckles, was thought provoking, and didn't just demonize the white guy. It showed both men's humanity and obvious flaws, and if it didn't make racism/segregation seem horrid, it didn't make it look nice. After playing to standing ovations, the good doctor still had to use the outhouse and drive to the colored cafe to eat.This movie has been lambasted by the PC crowd as too soft on racism (debatable) and too much from the Italian's viewpoint - true, but why is that a crime?. I suspect their real gripe is that Whitey made this film. Well, they can gripe, but most like the movie, and rightfully so.

title: Highly Interesting Movie

The one that appeals to me the most is the movie challenges many of our conventional perceptions - A white driver working for a black boss, a white man with limited exposure to cultured language and social skill against a black man with much more exposure, a black man with more exposure to Western music and culture than American black music and culture, etc.
Good plot! Good acting! Good cinematography! What more can one expect from a movie?

title: A friendship without borders
content:
'Green Book' is a film full of feelings and emotions. We start from the classic and widely used base already from a very different couple from which an unexpected friendship arises. In this case, between an African-American pianist and his Italian driver. The atmosphere generated by this relationship results in a film full of sentimentality and extremely funny situations. That is the strongest point of this tape.
However, just as it does the humorous part perfectly, the dramatic part is pretty weak. His representation of racism at that time is weak and very softened, with situations that do not fully frame the segregation that African Americans were forced to live. And when it tries to be dramatic, it exaggerates it, including situations to force the viewer's feeling.
However, outside of that it is a complete film, with a direct narrative and good performances. It tells the story without more or less, it does not risk anything, but it does not lose anything either, making it a film that can certainly please anyone, this being its greatest achievement in what it is offering.

title: Understated, Genius and Hella Funny
content: Brilliant actors Ali and Mortensen team up to deliver great understated performances in a friendship-heavy road movie that tackles America's 1960's segregration troubles. And yes, you should definitely put it on.Right off the bat, this is not a tearjerker nor a moralistic film at all. In fact it's a film that just shows you what it is, as a sophisticated black piano player with a lot of courage drives from show to show in the deep white South, backed by his hard-as-nails Italian driver.It's a very welcome way of portraying heartbreaking practices in society, keeping its focus on the good we have inside, especially between these two unlikely friends. It pulls a trick to achieve this, deliberately skipping the hard moments and only showing the aftermaths, stripping it from too much drama.The camera just never loses sight of either of our friends, and that makes it an exceptionally good film. Also, it has a mad sense of superb humour, and some great music to top it all of.It's heartwarming, understated and funny when you least expect it. What more would you want to put this on.

title: Great Story, Great Acting
content: Though "Green Book" has won a library-full of awards, many critics have been lukewarm about its merits. That is because they wish to see it as a commentary on race relations in the U.S. That is like viewing "My Cousin Vinny" as a commentary on the American judicial system.The film, based on a true story, is about the dynamics of a relationship between two men from different stations and cultures. Tony (Viggo Mortensen) is a meatball hired to drive Dr. Shirley (Mahershala Ali), an erudite black man, on a concert tour that passes through the deep South. Written, in part, by the son of real-life Tony, it is a rewarding story of education and transformation that provides both laughter and tears.The pace of the film is perfect. The viewer feels like a third passenger in the car as it motors from venue to venue, state to state, while a charming battle of wills evolves. And 1962 is created so accurately---through props and locations, wardrobe and music---that you can practically smell the rooms they have staged.This is definitely one of the best films of 2018.

title: Green Book Review
content: Viggo Mortensen delivers a transformative performance as Tony Lip, embodying his rough-edged, street-smart character with authenticity and depth. Mortensen's portrayal captures Tony's initial ignorance and prejudice, as well as his gradual awakening and growing respect for Shirley. Mahershala Ali, in an Academy Award-winning performance, portrays Dr. Don Shirley with elegance and complexity. Ali's nuanced performance reveals the loneliness and dignity of a man navigating a world that respects his talent but rejects his identity.The film's strength lies in the chemistry between Mortensen and Ali, whose dynamic performances bring humor, tension, and genuine emotion to their characters' evolving relationship. Their journey together, guided by the "Green Book," a travel guide for African-Americans during segregation, exposes them to the harsh realities of racism and challenges their preconceptions about each other and the world around them.

title: A good look at America's prejudices and society that fostered segregation in the 20th century
content: "Green Book" is a very good film, set in 1962, billed as a biographical comedy and drama. The film was inspired by true events that year when Don Shirley toured the Deep South accompanied by Frank Vallelonga. Shirley was a black classical pianist and Vallelonga, known as "Tony Lip," was an out of work white bouncer from New York's Copacabana Night Club. In true order of content, this film is first a drama, then biography, and then comedy. It's a film about prejudice, family, racism, class distinction, success, opportunity, and the social constrictions of the period.This was in the time just before the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Opposition to the racist laws and policies of the Deep South had increased since the 1955 Montgomery, Alabama, bus boycott by Rosa Parks. Major civil rights efforts were yet to come. Very little attention has been paid to the segregation practices and beliefs of the Deep South since then. What depictions there have been tend to paint the racial prejudice as being perpetrated mostly by rednecks. But this film shines the spotlight on the wealthy, upper class, and high society of the white South. One can't help but wonder how long segregation in the South otherwise would have lasted, or if it would have survived the Civil War at all. If the upper class whites, professionals, educators, businesses, churches and individuals had shunned racism and decried segregation, it surely couldn't have taken hold or survived so long.This is a good film and a good story. It also shines the light on prejudices within races. In Tony's case, within ethnic groups, although he is seen to initially harbor ill thoughts of blacks. And, in Don's case, inner-racial prejudice is based on status, upbringing, background, and education. But, if humanity isn't reason enough to end and abolish racism, the film shows that other social factors can help do so. In this case it's music - among the blacks and working classes of all color. Yet, the white elites don't even waiver in their prejudice in the face of great talent and art.This is a very good film for any time. It won three Oscars including best picture and best supporting actor for Mahershala Ali who plays Dr. Donald Shirley. The movie and Ali also won the Golden Globes that year.Here are some favorite lines from this film.Tony Lip, spotting a big billboard as they drive south out of Ohio, "Kentucky fried chicken - in Kentucky! When's that ever gonna happen?"Dr. Donald Shirley, looking over Tony's letter to his wife, "Dear Dolores - D-E-A-R! This is an animal," pointing to Tony's spelling.Tony Lip, "So, can I put, uh, 'P. S. Kiss the Kids?'" Dr. Don Shirley, " A P. S.?" Tony, "You know, at the end?" Dr. Shirley, "That's like clanging a cowbell at the end of Shostakovich's Seventh." Tony, "Right! And that's good?" Dr. Shirley, "It's perfect, Tony."Tony Lip, "You know, the world's full of lonely people waitin' to make the first move."

title: A Pleasant Surprise
content:
Both Lead actors give great performances in this humorous, charming, interesting and modest film.
Many times throughout the film I was waiting for an over the top, unrealistic display of the characters morals. I am very glad that this never happened, great credit to the Director for allowing the smaller moments to carry the film. In doing so you are given time to think about all these moments and what they mean to you and the characters. These characters evolve through the film as they both learn about themselves and each other. Again not shown with grand gestures but with small changes, just how the main theme of Racism needed to be changed and still does even to this day.
The modesty of the film sets itself apart from other films of its type. It doesn't feel the need to shove its important themes down in your face but hope you have the openness to acknowledge them.
Both Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali are well worth the watch and both deserving of award nominations as well as the Director Peter Farrelly.
A lovely film that has it all.

title: The Vidiot Reviews...
content: Green BookThe hardest part of driving through the southern US is convincing folks the internal combustion engine isn't witchcraft.Sadly, the driver in this drama must also persuade southerners that his black passenger is human.When nightclub bouncer Frank Vallelonga (Viggo Mortensen) is laid off, he takes a job driving around jazz pianist Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali) as he plays throughout the lower states. While the lowbrow Vallelonga and the snobbish Shirley struggle to find common ground, they eventually become friends and learn to navigate the racism embedded in the south.Loosely based on a true story, many liberties were taken to make this interracial buddy movie more palatable to modern day audiences. And while the freedom taken can be called into question, the overall message of tolerance is inarguable, along with the strong performances.And while having a white male driver may curtail racial violence, road rage incidents would double. content: I thoroughly enjoyed this movie, a serious underlying theme of racism in America, brought to the screen with just to the right degree of humor.

title: Good movie, but not up to the hype
content: It's a good movie, very well acted and directed, and with several quite funny moments; both main actors do a great job in my opinion. But the film does not surprise you, the story is not special and you end up with a bittersweet taste. Having won so many awards, I would have expected something more memorable, with some plot twist or unexpected scene near the end.

title: You Gotta Be Kidding
content: 8.2!! Do NOT fall for this rating. I have never seen so many cliches and overacted/overdramatized scenes crammed into a movie in my life. It has the slick and polished production, but that can't overcome the steady stream of nonsense this movie dribbles forth. Sadly, these are the types of movies Viggo always seems to stumble upon, and honestly I don't think he possesses the talent to tackle anything of real substance. This movie had very strong subject matter but the handling and production was 2nd rate at best. The best thing here is the music and the cars of that era. Skip it. There's way better movies on racial tensions out there that aren't a laughable mess. Mississippi Burning. A Time To Kill. Avoid this stinker.

title: Great movie!
content: I really loved this movie.It is one of my favourite movies.Great story and great performances from the actors.I highly recommend this movie.

title: What a great movie
content: Absolutely love everything about this amazing movie.

title: Good
content:
Good. Honest. See it twice.
Loved it.......

title: Brilliant film!
content: An excellent film with a fantastic performance by the leads...VM should have got the Oscar! Made me laugh out load...I loved his character....don't miss it!

title: Will make you cry and be amazed
content: Biopic of Dr Don Shirley & his driver Tony Vallelonga on the Shirley Trio's tour through the midwest & deep south. A well written, acted & filmed piece. Well worth watching. The music will bring calm to your soul. The pacing was spot on allowing for development of the relationship between our main characters. You will find yourself feeling the full gamut of emotions. The movie is especially relevant to these times.

title: Couldn't possibly be more cliché... it's good!
content:
Is this the 2018 Oscar deserving movie?
How? It's not much more than a big cliché made movie!The music tells us when we are supposed to feel things. The stereotypes start and end where generally they do in these type of "feel good movies", with the mandatory redemptive scenes for both parties, because "of course we know" are always "both parties fault", just to make sure nobody gets too offended.Everything is calculated, cold. No decision artistic. Everything "acceptable" but forgettable.
Anyways. The movie is good, because it looks great, the pace is great, the music and dialogue fun and the actors good.
But still, the movie and story is so simplistic and forgettable, that is a shame this gets to be "best of the year".

title: Opportunistic
content:
In real life, I especially hate those opportunistic things - just like the production intention of this movie.
So no matter how much (in some respects) it is praised, I will not give it - and such things - any good evaluation.

title: This is why I love movies
content: Like a drug addict searching for that great trip. I am always looking for a movie like this. All Hollywood should take notice - that great movies can still be made, but so rarely are.Absolutely enjoyable -10/10.

title: Haven't seen movie this good in a long time !
content: I just watched it last night. Those 2hrs passed quickly, kept my attention whole time and ended with smile on my face. Superb acting, overall just really well done, i still think about the movie.. 👌

title: You'll never eat pizza the same way again
content: A film with Poignant, evocative and challenging moments, marred only by a couple of elements that were a little trite. It wasn't necessary to include a 'not all cops' plot point, or to add the more jolting comedy elements. I'm not sure how the 'Tittsburgh' joke made it through the editing process, but it's undeniable that the performances from Mahershala Ali and Viggo Mortensen make Green Book well worth a watch.

title: Very boring
content: Nothing special. I didn't like it at all. Very boring movie.

title: Pure beauty
content:
Finally!!!
Finally a beautiful movie. Simply beautiful.
This film is a gift.
Now that most movies are just full of gratuitous violence, vulgarity, or simply awful, Green Book offers us an example of old style cinema. A simple but beautiful and captivating story, nicely filmed, with great dialogues, sublime acting, and great music.
Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali are immense, and the chemistry between them is so perfect.
I swear that if this movie loses the Academy Award for best movie in favor of The Favourite (one of the worst movies ever made), I will lose my faith in cinema awards forever.
Magnificent film, don't miss it!

title: Proof that racism shouldn't exist.
content: Regardless of your skin colour this film just proves that people can be friends and support each other throughout the hard times and the good times.

title: Movie based on stereotypical thoughts
content:
I admired the film & one cant deny the fact why it's a wonderful film to binge . Frankly this movie doesnt do much justice to the title Green book apart from few seconds where we are told what's it's about . There are scenes which anger you as well because there was so much prejudice between white & the black in the 60s .
Overall grab this film to watch but I wont call it a masterpiece

title: Shallow but appealing
content: If only things were this simple. But it's undeniably entertaining.

title: Simplistic & characters are not believable
content: One of the most overrated films I have seen. I saw it when it came out and was shocked by the Oscars. Did we see the same film? I mean, it's okay and fairly enjoyable for a simple, feel good sort of movie. But the actors are not believable at all, I'm aware they are "acting", the script is silly at times, and at no time did I get lost in the story. It felt more like a made for TV type of film. It's enjoyable and easy to watch and a lovely little story line but best picture? Seriously? And while Mahershala Ali deserved the Oscar for Moonlight (a stunning film) this win was a real stretch. He was not believable in this role and the dialogue was eye rolling worthy at times. Not his fault, he did the best he could with it. He's a great actor but I just felt the film was too shallow and trying too hard in the "feel good" department. I enjoyed it but compared to The Godfather? Gimme a break on the 10 stars lol. It wasn't the best year for movies so I can forgive the Oscar (my personal pick was The Favourite) but this is one seriously overrated film.

title: A very touching adventure and yet so funny adventure
content: Green book is one of those movies, that really stick into your head after days you ve watched it. The 2 main characters are so well performed, and the chemistry between them is stunning. Through this very emotional and some times ''sad'' joyrney, the film manages to give many funny moments, which results it to be an emotional rollercoaster in the end.

title: Did the film properly place the struggle of Black people in its rightful context?
content: Critical Review of Green Book - Rating: 7/10Green Book succeeds in delivering an enjoyable and engaging cinematic experience, with a screenplay that crafts well-developed, relatable characters within a lighthearted and accessible narrative. One of its greatest strengths lies in its ability to evoke emotions, particularly anger, in response to the racial discrimination depicted in the film. A movie that manages to provoke strong feelings in its audience demonstrates a certain level of cinematic effectiveness that cannot be overlooked.However, despite this emotional impact, the film suffers from several critical flaws, the most significant being its simplification of the struggle against racism, reducing it to a hopeful, reconciliatory journey rather than an urgent fight against systemic oppression. The central narrative focuses primarily on the white man's triumph over his own prejudice, rather than the Black man's battle against an entrenched system of racial discrimination. This framing reduces Don Shirley's character to a mere supporting element in Tony Lip's personal transformation, rather than making him the central figure in the story. The film could have been more compelling had it depicted a more realistic confrontation with racism-one that acknowledges that real struggles for equality often require more than passive resilience and that resistance can sometimes necessitate confrontation.It appears that the film deliberately took this approach to secure broader acceptance from American audiences, mainstream festivals, and global award circuits. Hollywood often favors narratives that provide an optimistic and palatable take on historical injustices, rather than confronting them with the harshness they deserve.Despite these shortcomings, Green Book deserves credit for successfully constructing complex character identities, particularly in its portrayal of Don Shirley, a man caught between two worlds-alienated from Black society yet never fully accepted by white society. This layered characterization adds depth to the story, yet it falls short of fully embracing the tragic dimensions that could have made Shirley's personal struggles even more compelling and emotionally resonant.Ultimately, Green Book is a well-crafted and emotionally engaging film, but it remains a safe, middle-ground choice, prioritizing reconciliation over confrontation. By offering a sanitized version of historical struggles, it diminishes its potential impact, making it less powerful than it could have been.
